awd_titl_txt: Molecules in Classical and Quantized Fields: Improving Time-Dependent Density Functional Approximations and Correlated Electron-Ion Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Neepa Maitra of Hunter College, City University of New York (CUNY) is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry. Dr. Maitra and her research group develop new methods for simulating the behavior of molecules exposed to light. Understanding and computationally modeling the motion of electrons and ions in molecules and solids far from their stable, equilibrium states is necessary for understanding photovoltaic processes, photocatalysis, radiation damage in biomolecules, nanoscale conductance devices, time-resolved pump-probe spectroscopies, and the production of compact light sources. Dr. Maitra's group develops theoretical methods from first-principles for computational simulations to reliably and efficiently predict these processes. Dr. Maitra organizes mini-workshops in electronic structure and dynamics open to the wider New York/New Jersey area.  She trains undergraduate and graduate students in cutting-edge research and uses innovative peer instruction teaching techniques in her undergraduate classes.

Dr. Maitra and her research group are developing new methods for the correlated dynamics of electrons, ions, and photons, in three aims. In one aim, improved functional approximations for time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) in the non-perturbative regime is derived.  This is built on an exact expression for the exchange-correlation potential. This research moves TDDFT towards use in real-time dynamics as confidently as DFT is used for ground-state properties. In the second aim, practical mixed quantum-classical methods based on the exact factorization approach for correlated electron-ion dynamics in laser fields are being constructed that include electronic decoherence and wave packet branching from first-principles. The third area extends exact factorization to light-matter systems to gain a fundamental understanding of how field quantization can alter and control chemical reactions, as well as to develop practical mixed quantum-classical methods for the dynamics and control of molecules in cavities. The research impacts topical applications where knowledge and understanding beyond ground-state electronic structure is needed, including photovoltaic design, and quantum control of electronic and nuclear dynamics by attosecond or femtosecond laser fields, or by tuning cavity parameters in polaritonic chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Accurate theoretical and computational modeling of the time-resolved dynamics of molecules remains a challenge today, yet an important one that impacts an increasingly wide range of applications, including photocatalyst design, the control of chemical reactions using laser fields, and, more recently, harnessing quantized light-matter interactions to manipulate properties of molecules. This project focussed on developing methodology rather than on specific applications, and in particular it advanced time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) for the description of the electrons, while developing the exact factorization (EF) approach for a first-principles treatment of correlated electron-ion motion. TDDFT is an established method of choice for electronic excitations and dynamics of molecules due to its favorable system-size scaling however the approximate TDDFT functionals used today have been found to perform poorly for some applications, particularly when the system is driven significantly away from a ground-state. Our work shed light on the features the approximations are missing by computing the exact functional, analyzed when these features lead to qualitatively large errors in the predictions, and constructed a new approximation that captures these features. Instabilities in our new approximation made it impractical, but opened the door to other possible constructions along these lines that may turn out to be more well-behaved.  Further, noting that the accuracy of an approximate functional depends on how close the domain it was derived under is to the domain of application, we explicitly showed that TDDFT errors in a commonly-used scheme that couples electrons to nuclei (Ehrenfest dynamics), are significantly reduced when the calculations are reformulated so as to use response quantities rather than real-time fully non-equilibrium quantities. One complication is that in this reformulation, couplings between excited states are required, and these show unphysical divergences at some excitation energies when the usual TDDFT approximations are applied. We derived a practical approximation that cures this divergence, and initial tests on small molecules were successful. 


Since the motion of electrons is coupled strongly to the motion of the ions in the molecule, a reliable accounting of electron-ion correlation is needed, and beyond-Ehrenfest methods are required.  We have been developing methods based on the recently proposed EF approach. EF is a general approach to deal with coupling between different quantum subsystems, enabling a rigorous way to include the effect that the motion of one quantum subsystem has on another. This project explored EF in three distinct directions. One was for electron-nuclear coupling phenomena, which was the original motivation for the EF. While a classical treatment of the nuclear motion is usually adequate, due to their much larger size, the influence of the quantum electronic system on the forces driving the nuclei is given rigorously by EF, and we made a detailed study of some recent mixed quantum-classical approaches, including the relevance and computation of central terms such as the nuclear quantum momentum. In a second direction, we derived a new quantum embedding method for strongly correlated electronic systems. The idea of embedding methods is that a large part of the system is treated at a lower level of theory than a key smaller part of the system, which can be one either of special importance or requiring a higher level due to the nature of the electron correlation there. The two treatments need to be linked by an embedding potential, and our method provides one derived from the EF; preliminary tests show much promise, encouraging future work in this area. In the third direction we extended the original EF to include photons as well in order to be able to simulate correlated dynamics occurring in polaritonic chemistry, an area that has recently seen burgeoning interest due to experimental advances harnessing quantized light-matter interactions to manipulate properties of matter. Approximations when using EF in this regime are subtle; for example, mixed quantum-classical methods may be justified for photons due to their harmonic nature rather than mass arguments as for the nuclear case, leading to different approximation techniques.  


The project led to the training of excellent postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates. People from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences were involved in the research, and exposed to a large scientific community through participation in national and international conferences, and visitors to the group. A significant part of the project occurred during the covid-19 pandemic, a challenging time especially for early graduate students and postdocs, lacking opportunities to present, discuss their work, and network with others in the field. To this end, in summer 2020, our group organized a Zoom PhD Student Seminar Series. This was a series of weekly seminars focussed on DFT and TDDFT theory development, with PhD students presenting 30-minute talks, and postdocs introducing them. We had six sessions of five talks each, with participation from more than 50 groups from around the world, and at times 100 people attending the zoom sessions.
